Update I'm about ready to just delete this one. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25084 is the one you want. Do not print this one. If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays Update I am now building these and selling these on my Etsy! So if you don't have a printer yet, I will be happy to print you one! Check it out at https://www.etsy.com/listing/109657227/ Thanks to those who printed the original Action Chess I learned a lot so I returned the the drawing board. While this assembles similarly to the original, every part has been adjusted somewhat. Improved base-to-base connections for the pawns and rooks, an improved king/queen conenction, and an improved overall design. If all things work out this should be a vast improvement over the original. And cooler looking. Plus I added a tinkercad logo to the chest for shameless pandering. (Well, I wanted a logo, but I couldn't design one that I liked, so I went with this.) Special thanks to PrettySmallThings for helping me with the couplers and for pointing out that I need to send my files through netfabb. This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/8kCHfmDya9y EDIT Made a version scaled by 80% so the pieces fit in the sizes specified by the contest rules. You can edit that version at https://tinkercad.com/things/03FJJx1dw3l

• Print aplate for all sides.
  • Insert the dial into the king (see illustration).
  • Play Chess.
    • To assemble in robot form:
  • Slide the tab from the queen into the notch on the king and slide downards to lock the body together.
  • Twist the dial to lock the king and queen together.
  • Take the 2 type A pawns and slide into the shoulder slots.
  • Take 4 type B pawns and lock their feet together to form 2 legs.
  • Flip the knights over for feet and snap the legs into them.
  • Snap the legs into the body.
  • Take the remaing 2 type B pawns and lock their feet into the feet of the rooks to form two upper arms.
  • Snap the shoulders pawns into the upper arms.
  • Snap the upper arm pawns into the bishops to form the hands.

comments.text: Great work!  This version is orders of magnitude improved over the previous.  I successfully printed everything from the V2 zip file.  I had to do a little bit of filing on the King/Queen interlocking tab -- the tolerances were a bit too tight on my print.  I also found that the Knights were a little tough to print.  I haven't verified by looking at the Z coordinates in Blender yet, but it felt like, after having ReplicatorG place the object on the platform, there was one small layer of just one end of the Knight (the horse's nose, if I recall correctly?) and then the actual structural base was printed as the second layer.  This made it not as sturdy as it could have been.  So the "floor" of the Knight might not be 100% even.  Again -- I haven't yet verified, it just felt that way during printing.

author: Rimom

description.text:
I'm disappointed with my AZ3 knobs, so i create these more comfortable ones, they make a very good difference:

-Tray knobs: I use 3pcs M5x25mm hex head bolts. Print 3pcs "trayKnob" and 3pcs "trayKnobBoltCover". Use contact glue for glue the covers after pressing the bolts.

-Slow movement knobs: I replaced the original ones. Print 2pcs "slowKnob". I use 2pcs M3x10mm hex allen bolts for fixing.

-Azimut brake knob: I replaced the original one. Print 1pcs azimutBrakeKnob. Redrill the main hole using a 8mm drill. I use a M4x16mm hex allen bolt and a M4 washer. Clean and use some contact glue on the rod before pressing into the knob, then press it and fix with the M4 bolt. (Note this part has a self contained support cylinder, remove it before assembling.)

-Tripod knobs: Print 3pcs, clean the holes, apply a contact glue drop on the original butterfly sides and press them into knob.

-Check out other AZ3 things:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2102051

-Updates: Feb/19/2017 Added tripod knobs and removed the "work in progress" flag of the thing.

Contribute by donating:

This designs has a lot of effort and testings, so please if you like it and found usefull consider to make a donation, any amount will be really apreciate and you will contributing with improved and future designs.

You can donate here: http://villamanydonate.blogspot.com

Thank you!

title: Tiny Whoop frame (Alternate)

description.text:
This frame is designed to use the 6mm motors and propellers known from our all time favorite tiny whoop (inductrix / e010) . The alternation is that this can fit a regular micro flight controller with the dimensions 33x20mm, or about so. This makes it possible to use for instance the F3 evo brushed flight controller with built in receiver, or derivates thereof. This means the frame is slightly wider than the regular tiny whoop.

This frame is experimental, and not yet properly tested, thus feedback appreciated

title: 1.75/3mm filament guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An insertable filament guide for guiding filament through a IKEA LACK tabletop into an enclosed buildchamber of sorts.

I uploaded various versions, a circular/hexagonal top, 1.75/3mm versions, and filleted/nonfilleted. For people that wish to remix this thing i also included the master .123d file containing every component i used.

Ideas for improvement are:
Adding 3-4 fins between the base and tube to prevent rotation (no glue needed!).
Modifying such that the base and stem are seperate parts. The tube would then be the main part, having a flat base which is screwed on (or glued on) the tabletop. The "base" can be printed as desired and clipped onto (or glued) the tube.

I took the idea of this filament guide from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1740538

Dimensions:
Circle/hexagon diameter: 3 cm (design 3 cm)
Circle/hexagon height: 1 cm (design 1 cm)
Tube length: 5 cm (design 5 cm) (V2/1.75mm = 5.5 cm)
Tube outer diameter: 5 mm (design 5.25 mm)
Tube inner diameter: ~2.4/3.25mm (design 2.6 / 3.4 mm)
Fillet if applicable: "setting 2"
Total length: 6 cm (V2/1.75mm = 6.5 cm)
Total width (diameter): 3 cm

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 um Z, 400 um xy

Infill:

i used 20%, but probably does not matter

Notes:

I only printed the 1.75mm filleted versions (PLA). Turned out the the tolances on V1 were too tight and i significantly increased the inner tube diameter to accommodate slightly bent or oval filament without too much friction.

The guides are supposed to be printed standing on the broad base (dimensions are corrected for smaller printed veritcal holes, see dimensions.). Even though printing in the length might result in less filament friction. I am going to see how this works out first

I intend to print using ABS later, 10mm/s, 242C extruder, 80C bed, certainly have to tweak cooling/temperature/speed. I am using a 400 um nozzle and going to use a 200 um layer height.
It is supposed to be a simple insert into a 5mm hole drilled through the tabletop of a IKEA LACK table. Add glue if desired.

description.text:
A co-worker told me he needed a thing to hold a thing. We searched the web for an stl but we found none. So he roughed out the basic thing in Tinkercad and sent it to me. We then printed it that out. It did not work. After some tweaking and several other prints we came to this version that works well.

This is designed to be a holder/case for the Ellipsis Jetpack Cellular hotspot.

As you can see in the photos we added some magnet tape to the back and it can now stick to any metal surface. You can also use double sided tape or industrial velcro which ever best suites your need.

remixed_from.title: colloidal silver heated magnetic spinner lab stirrer

description.text:
Just like the other but Tailored for Making extracts
it will rapidly evaporate solvents IE alcohol for making concentrates
or essential oils ect
i use it for concentrating Maca root

you need to print this in abs because of heat bed. print at 100% infill or it will tear itself apart warping i put felt pads on the bottom in the four corners

Spinner
40mm cpu fan 12v
10x2mm magnets x2
M3x60 and aquarium tubing for spacer

heat bed ( http://dirtypcbs.com/store/designer/details/peter.plaaswerf%40gmail.com/168/100x100mm-3d-printer-heated-bed )
a proto pack is 12 of them if i remember right
the heat bed helps speed up evaporation

555 pwm x2 ( scamatic is in pics )
allows you to control temp and spinner speed

Fan for #6 stopper
40mm cpu fan x1
There are some holes that need drilled IE to hold top on to mount fan inside and for heal bed
for 12v power supply i used xbox 360 power brick

You will need to modify the 555 pwm schematic for this project but if you cant see what needs changed you probably cant build the timer yourself anyway LOL.. It is the same timer you would use in a PWM box mod

if you dont like the Ag+ just flip the lid over

This is fully printable filament holder and easy swap of filament.
You can use if you have acrylic or PVC pipe as 38mm diameter.

There are two kind of set, Spool_Holder set is 110mm wide and Spool_Holder_S set is 85mm wide.

title: ANET A8 Printer bed mounted camera arm for Auto Level

description.text:
I've got auto bed leveling installed on my printer and wasn't really using the spring mounted bed adjusters anymore, so I hard tailed it with some printed spacers and a camera arm that mounts to the bed in place of one spacer.

I'm a little worried about the bed softening the spacers and arm mount, so I'm going to kill two birds with one stone and put some cork insulation on the bottom of the heated bed and use that to insulate the spacers from the heated bed.

I had tried some other mounts and most of those relied on friction to keep the camera positioned. I wanted something a little more positive, so made this to use some 3mm machine screws to keep everything nice adn tight.

So you will need to print the arm and 3 spacers if you want to do the same.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

comments.text: just curious... with most of us trying to reduce vibrations and jerky movement, wouldnt having this arm and camera attached to the printer bed cause artifacts in the prints??
comments.author: dflash0

comments.text: It's really light.  I'd bet that it weighs less than the glass bed itself and the flat cable really has no impact on it.
comments.author: dflash0

title: Adafruit Feather Rover chasis and top

description.text:
This is my version of a chasis and top to resemble Adafruit's aluminum chasis and top plate for their rover used in the Feather Rover and RPi Rover. I intentionally bought everything but these pieces to force myself to create my own. Even though they sorta resemble Adafruit's in spirit, everything is from my own measurements. It's still a work in progress, the 4xAA battery pack didn't quite fit like I wanted it to on the top (it's not an adafruit pack) so I resorted to tie-wrapping it until I can revise the model a little. But other than that, every thing lined up for the Feather build per their instructions (motor board and feather on the doubler) and fun has been had. It's a fun little project when complete and works as expected.

For spacers I used m3 40mm, customized version of thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:710249

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20%

See Adafruit's instructions

Adafruit's Bluefruit Feather Robot Rover instructions tells you everything you need to know.
https://learn.adafruit.com/bluefruit-feather-robot

title: FreeDeePee BedSlider GT2 - For USA Flat washer

description.text: This is a simple modification of litwan's Bed Slider for Makerslide used in his FreeDeePee 3D printer.  I modified the ID (11.8mm) of the part to accept a standard 6mm flat washer (6.5x11.8x1.5) from HomeDepot.   The original design requires a (7x11x2) flat washer that I could not find anyplace.

Print part.
Drill ID of M6 flat washer to.281 (Drill size K) to accept 7mm cam for V wheel
press flat washer into part as show in photo.

It's time for Wall-E! Again... This time it's not a huge multi-part robot that doesn't work. It's a small figure that is now a single piece and doesn't have spots for electronics inside.

Since I already had all the individual pieces modeled, I just had to assemble them and fill any gaps or holes. After that I went through and added extras here and there to make it print easy or stronger in specific areas.

After that my wife painted it using filler primer, followed by an airbrush for the yellow area, then paintbrush using acrylic paints for the remaining colors. And to wrap it up she sprayed it with an clear coat.

Print Settings:
Printer: Da Vinci 1.0 Pro
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Infill: 30%
Supports: Yes

comments.text: Thank you for making this model! Quite easy to print and VERY fun to paint.

description.text:
After trying out many different overhead spool holders, I realized that none had the outcome that i was looking for. I made this from scratch with the idea that it would be held together on both ends on the top with the spool rod and some nuts. The bottom has holes that end right where the old screen screw holes are. If you use it this way, the stock screen needs to be removed/relocated.
(not necessarily) Requires 2 m3X30 screws and two m3 nuts.
There is two nut holes on either side to allow for further compatibility.
You could also choose to not use a screw at all. (I dont judge)

title: Yamaha Baby Grand Piano Timbre Modifier

description.text:
This was my final project for Rhino 3D Modeling class in college, and I had to upload the files to Thingiverse as part of the requirements.
It does not work very well.
The red parts are 3D printed (Makerbot Replicator 1) and the beams that connect the two red parts are laser cut plywood. It requires specific nuts and bolts, and I unfortunately do not have the dimensions down. In order for this to be used, it requires modification.

• Print out the stl files. 3 shells, 20% infill, PLA.
  • Laser cut plywood plank (.23 in) using the dxf file.
  • Screw together the 3D prints and the laser cut plywood.
  • Attach them to the metal beams in your Yamaha Baby Grand Piano.
  • Play the piano and torment your neighbors.

title: Pulse Motors (Horizontal) for 1/4" or 8mm Shaft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pulse motors produce little to no heat on the induction coils when properly wired. That makes pla or abs acceptable as materials for these type of motors/generators to be made from.

This motor represents a tool for learning about the radiant spike energy that is produced when you pulse DC through a motor or induction coil. Most everyone is familiar with the work of Nikola Tesla. He experimented with pulsed DC and made claims that it was superior to AC. A more recent genius was John Bedini who made his work/designs free to the world for replicating and experimenting with. He had three patents for his work with pulsed DC energy which included work with pulsed motors. US Patent #6392370
US Patent #6545444
US Patent #6677730
He worked closely with individuals on this forum: http://www.energyscienceforum.com/forum.php which may be a good place to start for learning this technology.

There are parts for two variations of this motor here. One is for a quarter inch shaft and the other is for a 8mm shaft. Here is a parts list:

1/4" motor:
1/4" smooth rod obtained from http://www.vxb.com/ 6" should be sufficient.
1/4" X 3/4" X 9/32" bearings to fit in the printed bearing ends found at http://www.vxb.com/
1/2" X 1/4" X 2" neodymium magnets found at http://www.magnet4less.com/
6-32 X 1/2"L stainless or brass bolts from Lowes X4 (recommended but not necessary)
You can just clamp and glue if you choose.

8mm motor:
8mm smooth rod obtained from http://www.vxb.com/
8mm X 22mm X 7mm bearings found at any skateboard shop or http://www.vxb.com/
magnets are the same as above
6-32 X 1/2"L stainless or brass bolts from Lowes X4 (recommended but not necessary)
You can just clamp and glue if you choose.

A good choice for a circuit to start with would be :http://www.teslagenx.com/kits/tx-sg4tub.html?category=kits or http://www.teslagenx.com/kits/tx-sg8.html?category=kits
The wire and circuit are your choice. It would be easy to run it as an Air Core Bedini SSG. There are four stator positions on this motor. You can use one or all four. The direction of winding only makes it a push or pull type pulse motor. You can also operate it with a "make and break" point such as a commutator or magnetic reed switch.

You may need a 1/4" or 8mm drill bit to clear the way in the rotor for your shaft.

  • Also, sand all sharp edges to reduce the risk of cutting or scraping your magnet wire.

The optional drill points on the bottom of the motor braces are for installing an outer shell. A section of 4" diameter PVC from your local big box home improvement store should fit the bill nicely. You'll have to rely on some minor fabrication skills for that.

Disclaimer: You build and experiment with these models at your own risks. Catastrophic failure of parts moving at a high rate of speed can damage property, and cause injury or death.

01/24/2017 : I added a drill attachment to help make winding coils easier. You will need three 1.25" long 6-32 bolts and one 6-32 nut. It is made to attach to the end of a leg. You made need to sand sharp edges on the attachment to reduce the risk of cutting your wire. Be patient and don't spin too fast as there is a chance that you could yank your wire apart due to the elongated design.

title: Z-Sensor Bracket for Behind Front Fan

description.text:
TL;DR: 12mm and 18mm Sensor brackets which fits between the blower fan and extruder housing.

18mm: X offset = -20, Y offset = -57, BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION = 163
12mm: X offset = -17, Y offset = -56, BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION = 164

Update:
As requested, I have added a 12mm version. I don't own a 12mm sensor to try it with, but it should work (if you try it, please let me know in the comments whether it worked). The offsets for the 12mm version are: -17, -56 (x, y) and you'll be able to set your BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION to 164 as a result.

So, in preparation for adding a z-levelling sensor (18mm diameter) to my Anet A8, I went on a hunt for a suitable bracket. There are lots of great designs out there but everything I found which could fit my printer head had been designed to use the heatsink screws as a fixture. Nothing wrong with that, per sé, but I didn't really want to be moving my sensor every time I change filament, and I find removing the fan and heatsink is the easiest and fastest way to change the filament.

So, I designed a bracket which fits behind the blower fan at the front of the print head. I had to use 2 (luckily spare) of the M3 allen key headed screws in place of the ones which came as stock, as they are a couple of mm longer, but as you can see from the images, it all holds together nicely.

It's a nice and simple design, and it seems to work (the sensor hasn't fallen off, anyway, so that's nice).

I had to edit the offsets for the sensor (I am using Skynet v2.3.1 at the time of writing) to -20, -57 (x, y) and I had to update the BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION variable in Skynet's Arduino sketch to accommodate (I set it to 160 but 163 would be more precise).

description.text: http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2009/05/3d-printed_combination_lock.html http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Combination-Lock/ This was for a final project for my 3D modeling class. I went with a Combo lock. It was done to show how a basic combo lock works. Total size is 4 inches wide. 3.5 front to back and 2.5 tall and is made of 10 parts. I was going to do a Anniversary release of the files, but I am releasing it sooner because I get asked every once in a while about the .STL files or the Inventor.IPT files so here you go. Enjoy. Inventor IPT files are for Inventor 2009

Print one of each part. Print 3 of the spacers. 
SLT files can be downloaded separately, or a zip file that has all of the STL files in it.

comments.text: Some suggestions on my build using Cura as slicer. Almost all the parts are assumed inches so they are very tiny in Cura. I applied a scale of 25.4 to these parts. For Rotor 3, I also added an extra 25% to Z so the scale factor for that part was X,Y,Z=25.4,25.4,32. The spacers were a different story. They were huge. For them I found a scale factor of .0254 worked well. I used supports for all parts except the two dials and spacers. Finally Rotor 2 can go in two different ways (forward or backward). One way makes the combination too weird with the second and third number practically the same. So flip Rotor 2 around if you have that issue.

Thumbwheel with built-in nut to replace the factory wingnuts. Designed it to go with JMW Concepts bed leveling mod (found here - https://youtu.be/sOXuJFgiM24), but could be used for anything with an M3 nut.

Paused the print at layer 24 and inserted standard M3 nut. I sprayed the top of the nut with hairspray and let it preheat on the bed while printing to help with the next layer adhering. Worked great.

The part file is included to make any changes as needed.

**Update - I'm working on getting the tolerances better and hopefully i'll come out with a set of more sizes soon (M4, M5, etc.).

title: FX798T & Battery Strap mount for Snappy Micro Brushless Frame

description.text:
Just a FX798T camera mount and a battery strap plate with 20x20 mounting holes for the snappy frame. Both were modified from Doinker components serving the same purpose.

The base of each part should line up with the contour of the opening where the electronics are mounted. I use M3 nylon screws/bolts to mount the plates and to get the camera plate even w/ the top of the frame.

Going to make solid versions of the plates soon so the compartment can be completely sealed for a somewhat gunk/water resistant setup.

Edit: the bottom battery strap plate was meant to sit on top of the mounting brackets connected to the frame. The middle portion should line up w/ the bottom of the frame.

title: Tiny 3-Axis CNC Keyboard Control over USB Serial

description.text:
Using this sketch you can control the Tiny 3-Axis CNC over the USB serial. Upload the sketch to your Adruino and then open the Arduino IDE's serial monitor (keyboard shortcut: Ctrl+Shift+M). The keys are "WSAD" and "OL". They work as follows: W = forward
S = back
A = left
D = right
O = up
L = down To operate the Tiny CNC, type one or more (WSADOL) commands into the serial monitor and hit Enter.

author: drmcland

title: LED USB candle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
https://youtu.be/d8oGNrZc4sU
https://youtu.be/tYhKVuVkttQ

DISCLAIMER
I used a flashing RGB lED for this project, however you can use any 5mm LED you choose. You can have it a solid color, slow changing or even a flickering candle LED.
If it's a 5mm LED it will fit. Just keep in mind that this setup will allow 27mA of current through the LED series. This is the high end to ensure maximum brightness please ensure your LED can comfortably handle this current. Failing that you can put a larger resistor a 200 ohm will produce 25mA, a 250 ohm 20mA and a 300ohm 16mA.

(For the more tech savvy thees calculations deliberately ignore the forward voltage of the LED as a way to ensure a safety buffer so don't bother trying to correct my math =)

INSTRUCTIONS

This was a simple project to replace the battery powered RGB LED candle in a night light I built for my son.
I originally designed the nightlight to work with an RGB LED candle from Ebay link below.
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/New-10-20-30-PCS-LED-WEDDING-TEA-LIGHT-TEALIGHT-CANDLE-FLICKERING-FLAMELESS/201168843821?_trksid=p2045573.c100033.m2042&_trkparms=aid%3D111001%26algo%3DREC.SEED%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D39923%26meid%3D53157d5a5e5e44468c973e67e06549d3%26pid%3D100033%26rk%3D3%26rkt%3D8%26sd%3D172158427096

To make this you will need a few things.
I used 1 - 3 5mm RGB Fast flashing LEDs link below
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/5-8mm-LED-0-25-0-5W-Straw-Hat-Red-Blu-Grn-Whi-Fast-Slow-6Color-Waterclear-Emitt/252568823084?_trksid=p2045573.c100033.m2042&_trkparms=aid%3D111001%26algo%3DREC.SEED%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D39923%26meid%3D53157d5a5e5e44468c973e67e06549d3%26pid%3D100033%26rk%3D2%26rkt%3D8%26sd%3D172158427096
a 180 ohm resistor link below
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/100pcs-1-4W-Watt-0-25W-Metal-Film-Resistor-180ohm-1-precision-/172158427096?hash=item2815711fd8:g:X6oAAOSwZ8ZXBERL
and just an old USB cable.

To make it all you need to do is cut off the unused end of the USB cable.
Strip back the insulating and shielding to expose the following wires.
Red = 5V+
Black = 0v or GND
White = Data +
Green = Data -

You don't need the white or green for this so cut them back and insulate them with tape.
Simply connect the red 5v+ wire to the anode of the LED (longer lead)
Solder the 180 ohm resistor to the cathode of the LED and the black wire from the USB to the other end of the resistor.

Remember to check it's operation in an old phone charger or a battery bank before plugging it into your expensive laptop or PC!!!!!

title: Syma X5 808 Keychain Camera Mount!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I wanted to get 1080 video out my Syma X5H so mixed up my Syma X5 mount with a very nice mount for 808 Keychain camera I found on Thingiverse to get this! Weights in just 5 grams over the stock camera!

Also here is the link for the camera if your interested (1080P 120 Degree Wide Angle 808 Keychain Camera Motion Activated Portable Pocket DV Action Cam): http://amzn.to/2iLeVeL

In addition, we created this video https://youtu.be/3_l6yqNTcQQ to show more of this neat little design! Also if you looking for your own 3D printer to create stuff like this, check out this one https://youtu.be/3_l6yqNTcQQ as I highly recommend it.

Be sure to also visit our drone site (http://Video-Drone.Diy3Dtech.com) for more info on this build!

title: Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro Belt Clip for Y Axis

description.text:
This is similar to the belt clip I made for the X axis of the Geeetech Prusa I3. It allows (requires) you to put a 180 degree twist in the belt so the teeth of the belt don't run over the smooth idler wheel as they shouldn't.

The piece can be attached to the carriage by using either 3mm machine screws or sheet metal screws threaded into the plastic. The hole depth is 16 mm, so keep that in mind when selecting screws. Anything much longer will run into the belt slot

I made this last year at the request of a user of the X axis belt clip I made. I never printed one so I asked for feedback from those that downloaded it. When I received no comments, I removed it.

Later, I made one for a family member when they built a Geeetech I3, so I think it's safe to say it works, although I have not used one myself. On my printer I just put a twist in the belt and fastened it to the aluminum block furnished, and I haven't had any reason to change from that.

If you find a problem, let me know and I'll make some changes.

I used PLA for this. It's stronger than ABS and holds threads beautifully if you are careful while cutting them.
Update 1/28/17 So far, I've developed a preference for screws threaded into PLA where practical, but if you want to use 3 mm machine screws and nuts, let me know and I'll add a version to accommodate them.

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro Dual

No

No

0.3 or 0.2 mm

20 or 30% should be plenty

Notes:

Use a min of 2 perimeters, and preferably 3. It will be mostly solid at 3 perimeters.

Tap the holes with the screws you are going to use. Use a soldering iron applied to the head of the screw and heat it until the plastic softens. Advance the screw until it cools to the point where it gets harder to turn, and then reheat (but not too much).

description.text:
EDIT: 04/22/2017
I ordered bearings from E3D and so far they are working great! So just forget the cheap stuff and get these.
http://e3d-online.com/623ZZ?search=M-BEARINGS-623

WARNING: I have used cheap bearings and expensive bearings and both have failed....
I am only finger tightening the bottom part and the bearings are still falling apart. Why cant I get good quality bearings even if I'm paying 26 bucks for 10 of them!!!
When its working it works GREAT! But until I can get bearings that wont fall apart I cant recommend this upgrade.... If you know a source where I can get REAL quality bearings please message me. The last ones I used where supposed to be hybrid bearings which are both ceramic and steal... Sadly they have not proven to be any better than the cheap ones as far as I can tell....

Notes:

I made these for my highly modified Robo3DR1+.

Robo 3D owners rejoice! And anyone else who wants to adapt their printer to ADJUSTABLE roller bearings.
After needing to replace my Y axis bearings for the 4th time since owning my Robo3D I came across good_idea and his 8MM bearing blocks http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1424346 . I looked at linear rails but just couldn't see a way to make them work with the Robo3D. Desperate for a better smooth rail solution I designed a new pillow block for the Robo adding in these bearing blocks only to find out that they almost immediately had slop in them! This made me mad since I really had high hopes that this was the solution! So I set out to make it better and ADJUSTABLE! So, if they loosen at all I can simply pull my print surface up and make the adjustment.
After the initial installation they seemed a bit tight even with little tension of the adjustment screws so I moved the axis back and forth many times by hand until it loosened up a bit and it is now functioning very well.

**I think the reason I had trouble after the initial installation is because I was printing them with the previously newly installed bearing blocks from good_idea. they worked well enough to get a print off but I'm sure if they had been more accurate I wouldn't have had the breakin problem. I also modified after my print to leave more room for the bearings.

NOTE: I had to move the drive belt pulley, and roller bearings up a few milometers. I put a few large washers under the roller bearings and adjusted the pulley up.
After inserting the nuts in the side of the block I put some foil tape over them so they wouldn't fall out. I would suggest this or maybe a drop of glue.

The files included are newer than the pics.
I used these bearings from Amazon https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBF3JO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

NOTE:
After having one of the cheap bearings fail on me pretty quickly I am upgrading them to these. https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-10PCS-3X10X4mm-S623-2OS-CB-ABEC7-LD-3x10x4-Stainless-steel-hybrid-ceramic-ball/32596349454.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.qj8K6t

NOTE:
I've been running the Y axis blocks for about a month now and I have yet to have to adjust them at all. Both Y and X axis's are still using the cheap steal bearings in initially installed. Thus far the Y axis has had no problems with these cheap bearings. I'm still running it like this until my new ones arrive. There is a clicking now and then and I believe it has been the reason for a missed step from time to time so I'm looking forward to seeing how the hybrid bearings do.

When installing these I didn't tighten them much at all! Barely snugged them up and they have been great ever since. I think the extra money spent on the better bearings will be worth it in the long run.

title: X-Wing Ship Outlines in STL and OpenSCAD (X-Wing TMG)

description.text:
This is a conversion of Geordan Rosario's x-wing miniatures font into STL and OpenSCAD for use in 3D modeling. I spent the time to figure out how to do the conversion and thought I'd just share the output.

If they look odd, it's because they are extruded maybe more than they should be. Anyone who needs to use these for booleans, etc., should find it trivial to adjust that.

The license on Geordan Rosario's font is actually an MIT license, which has been included in the files.

(This is on a Mac.)

git clone https://github.com/geordanr/xwing-miniatures-font.git
cd xwing-miniatures-font/dist/
cp *.ttf ~/Library/Fonts/

Open up Inkscape, select the font, type a character, object to path, path to OpenSCAD.

Rinse and repeat.

The V1 is obsolete. This post is for product support and legacy. No sugar added! It basically combines the holder of the J-Head, the heat sink of the Budaschnozzle, and the hot end of the MK7. The J-Head Lite uses a 1/2" reprocessed PTFE holder with a 6mm stainless steal tube whereas a traditional J-head uses a 5/8 PEEK holder with an 8mm PTFE lined brass tube. The heat sink is actually just a simple plumbing cap with a hole through it and mounted with a brass nut: simple, low tech, effective. The hot end is based off of the MK7, except it uses a 3w resistor and a thermistor instead of a 40W heater and a thermocouple. I tried to take the best parts of "the big 3" hot end designs and make something that's an economical alternative for ABS/PLA printing. Did I mention it's only 1.5oz? After probing around the hot end at 240C with a thermistor, I found the brass nut on the heat sink gets to 170C, the middle of the stainless steal tube gets to 110C and the top gets to 80C. To be on the safe side, I'll call the max temp 250C. Made out of:
1/2" PTFE rod (McMaster-Carr # 8803K14)
Laser cut oak mounting plate (Lowes 1/4" Oak)
M6x1 stainless steal barrel (McMaster-Carr # 90024A461)
Aluminum heater block (Clinton Aluminum .3750X.5000 FLT 6061)
Vishay 6.8ohm resistor (Digikey # RWMA-6.8CT-ND)
Honeywell 100k thermistor (Digikey # 480-3135-ND)
Brass nozzle (McMaster-Carr # 8952K33)
Ceramic insulation (Mcmaster-Carr # 87575K85)
Heat Resistant Wiring (skygeek.com # M22759/16-22-0)
Copper Heat Sink (McMaster-Carr # 5520K44) Instead of using a brass barrel, I use a stainless steal barrel, much like what is used in the current Makerbot extruder design. I, and they, did this because stainless steal has less thermal conductivity than brass. This means less heat travels up the barrel. I also added a heat sink which mounts to the top of the heater block, separated by ceramic insulation. The brass nut, which clamps the heat sink down, absorbs heat as it travels up the barrel and dissipates it through the heat sink. The PTFE is separated from the heat sink by air, which is actually a great insulator. Simply by not touching the PTFE, the heat sink is unable to transmit its thermal energy through conduction. This thermal management helps resists thermal expansion in the PTFE. Thermal expansion is the cause of PTFE loosening during extrusion. As the amount of force required to push the filament down the barrel and through the nozzle is much less with 1.75mm filament vs. 3mm filament (2-3 times less I think), less force is ultimately required to keep the barrel in place. So, with the right thermal management and the smaller filament size, PTFE is a pretty effective and economical alternative to PEEK. Although It doesn't look like a very complex design, it's sometimes easier to do more with less and there's quite a lot of interesting thermodynamics going on here. With this minimalist design, a respectable hot end can be made at a fraction of the cost vs. a traditional J-Head. Hence, I deemed it the J-Head Lite. PLA USERS:
Soak a cotton ball with vegetable oil and feed the filament through it in order to stop it from sticking.
http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2010/02/06/oil-helps-pla-yes/ Some of the earlier batches of heater blocks were machined a little tight. If it's too tight for the heater, either ream out the hole a little, or contact me for a replacement on ebay. The .stl file is for reference only. Do not attempt to print your own J-Head lite. For 1.75mm filament only. Please note, the J-head Lite has not been tested on nylon or polycarbonate.
Thanks to http://alexcphoto.com for the printable mount.
Buy one: http://stores.ebay.com/ohpakron
See it in action: http://youtu.be/oHNYAnzMJ2A Atribution! Atribution! Atribution!
Hotends.com, the original J-Head developers. a bit pricey for my taste, but without their dedication to open source tech, my business would not be possible. Thanks bros.

Things needed:
Kapton tape
PTFE tape
Permatex anti-seize lubricant -optional
Heat sink compound -optional
Vice grip
Wrench
Wire stripper
Scissors
Solder
Soldering iron
2mm drill bit
6mm drill bit
10mm socket wrench bit, reamed to at least 6mm
All are available at your local hardware store or Radio Shack, except Kapton tape, which can be found from various online sources: Grainger, McMaster-Carr, Ebay, etc. This process may take an hour or longer. These instructions are highly complicated. The risk of burning and/or electrocuting yourself is very high. Wear appropriate safety gloves while handling hot metal and live wires. I encourage novice users to not attempt this assembly. Prep: Soak the heater block, the steel tube, and the nozzle in acetone or laquer thinner to remove residual cutting oil and/or particulates, which may jam the nozzle. -optional
  • Put some anti-seize lubricant on the nozzle threads and screw it into the block. Make sure it's tight.
  • Take the small PTFE tubing and cut it into 4 parts. Put it on the leads of the thermistor and resistor.
  • Coat the resistor with heat sink compound and insert the thermistor and resistor into the heater block.
  • Cut the "Tefzel" wire into 4 equal parts and strip them.
  • Solder the leads of the resistor and thermistor to the wires and insulate the joint with Kapton tape.
  • Wrap the block with the ceramic insulation and secure with Kapton tape.
  • Coat about 1/3 from the bottom of the steel barrel with a 1/4" worth of heat sink compound.
  • Screw the brass nut onto the middle of the steel barrel.
  • Wrap both ends of the barrel with PTFE tape; 1/4" at the bottom, 1/2" on the top.
  • Put the heat sink onto the barrel.
  • Screw the barrel into the heater block.
    Note: The end of the barrel that's countersunk is the top. Screw in the flat side.
  • Attach the wires of the hot end to your controller board.
  • Heat the hot end to 255C (smoke is normal).
  • Take a pair of vice grips and clamp it to the top of the barrel.
  • Take a wrench and screw the nozzle and the barrel together.
  • Take a 10mm socket wrench bit and tighten the brass nut down onto the heat sink.
  • Thread the PTFE holder onto the barrel hand tight.
  • Wait 2 minutes
    Note: This part is delicate. It's very easy to strip the threads on the PTFE, because it's soft material.
  • Slowly tighten the PTFE holder onto the barrel hand tight. Do not over tighten. Do not under tighten.
  • Let cool.
  • Take a 2mm drill bit and ream out the PTFE holder.
    Note: I find it's best to use vice grips and clamp the drill bit to hand ream the hole. I'm looking for alternatives to this step, but that's the best I've got for know.
  • Take the wood mount and carefully insert it into the groove mount. The wood can break.
    • These PID settings are a good place to start:

comments.text:
The copper gets pretty hot and it seems to be very effective. It's
actually the brass nut that conducts the heat from the barrel into the
heat sink. It's necessary to prevent the PTFE from overheating. The PTFE is there to insulate the barrel from the x carriage,
so you can use plastic or wood without the heat destroying it.

title: USB flashing Iceberg Night light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This was a simple project to replace the battery powered RGB LED candle in a night light I built for my son.
I originally designed the nightlight to work with an RGB LED candle from Ebay but decided a USB plug in variant was the way to go.

I used a flashing RGB lED for this project, however you can use any 5mm LED you choose. You can have it a solid color, slow changing or even a flickering candle LED.
If it's a 5mm LED it will fit. Just keep in mind that this setup will allow 27mA of current through the LED series. This is the high end to ensure maximum brightness please ensure your LED can comfortably handle this current. Failing that you can put a larger resistor a 200 ohm will produce 25mA, a 250 ohm 20mA and a 300ohm 16mA.

(For the more tech savvy thees calculations deliberately ignore the forward voltage of the LED as a way to ensure a safety buffer so don't bother trying to correct my math =)

To make this you will need a few things.
I used 1 - 3 5mm RGB Fast flashing LEDs link below
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/5-8mm-LED-0-25-0-5W-Straw-Hat-Red-Blu-Grn-Whi-Fast-Slow-6Color-Waterclear-Emitt/252568823084?_trksid=p2045573.c100033.m2042&_trkparms=aid%3D111001%26algo%3DREC.SEED%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D39923%26meid%3D53157d5a5e5e44468c973e67e06549d3%26pid%3D100033%26rk%3D2%26rkt%3D8%26sd%3D172158427096
a 180 ohm resistor link below
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/100pcs-1-4W-Watt-0-25W-Metal-Film-Resistor-180ohm-1-precision-/172158427096?hash=item2815711fd8:g:X6oAAOSwZ8ZXBERL
and just an old USB cable.

To make it all you need to do is cut off the unused end of the USB cable.
Strip back the insulating and shielding to expose the following wires.
Red = 5V+
Black = 0v or GND
White = Data +
Green = Data -

You don't need the white or green for this so cut them back and insulate them with tape.
Simply connect the red 5v+ wire to the anode of the LED (longer lead)
Solder the 180 ohm resistor to the cathode of the LED and the black wire from the USB to the other end of the resistor.
Insulate all connections with tape, hot glue and or heatshrink

Remember to check it's operation in an old phone charger or a battery bank before plugging it into your expensive laptop or PC!!!!!

title: Common Dual Extruder Wire Loom Strain Relief

description.text:
This part replaces the upper black plastic deck that sits above the extruders on a common MK10 Dual Extrusion printhead design found on FlashForge, PowerSpec, Wanhao, .... The purpose: To provide a strain relief for the wire loom coming out off the printhead and more importantly to prevent the stiff brittle thermocouple wires they use in so many of these printers from flexing to much at a sharp angle at the edge of the stock black plate. These wires can not be fixed once they brake and the entire thermocouple has to be replaced and re-routed through the long loom. (I may have made it 2 weeks of constant printing before the thermocouples broke on 1 head, followed by the other. Since I designed and installed this, I have had no issues (knock on plastic)).

There are several other versions of this already designed and uploaded but each of those seemed to be tweaked for the dimensions related to other mods the designer was already performing on their printers. This design is pour to the stock OEM dimensions for where the filament enters the stepper and where the screw holes align. I also provide an extra tall shoulder for the feed tubes to sit in so they are less likely to kick out and hang (not really an issue but keeps things where they belong). I suggest printing in PETg or even ABS but not PLA since this is in the hottest general area of the printer; plus the steppers themselves can get pretty hot and PLAs softening temperature is pretty low (you may be fine, give it a try).

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Supports are required for the Tie Wrap separators. I suggest printing in PETg or ABS.

title: Magnetic Suspension Motor/Generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This apparatus represents a tool for learning about the interaction of spinning opposing magnetic fields. It is a variation of the David Hamel Spinner. http://peswiki.com/directory:david-hamel-motor

This project is discussed here: http://www.energyscienceforum.com/showthread.php?t=3766

You can add modules to see how tall you can stack the rotors. You can experiment with using pulse coils to spin it. You can enclose it to experiment with ion trapping.

Parts List:

3/4" diameter metal or glass disc with a small pivot point drilled/tapped in the middle (at least 1) this point will need to be oiled
5" weaving needle (at least 1) for the rotor. cut to desired length
1/2" X 1/4" disc neodymium magnets outer ring X16 from http://www.magnet4less.com/
5/16" X 1/8" disc neodymium magnets inner ring X12 from Harbor Freight or http://www.magnet4less.com/
1/4" cube magnets for pulse motor rotor X4 (optional)
small bundles of welding wire for the pulse motor coil cores (optional)
1/8" threaded rods at 12" (optional) X4 to use with the outer ring that does not have stilts attached.
magnet wire of choice for pulse motor coils (optional)

Some drilling and sanding may be required for optimum fitting.

This apparatus is 4" in diameter.
To this date there has never been a known successful replication of the actual Hamel device. Experiment at your own risk. Catastrophic failure of parts spinning at high speed can cause damage to property, injury, or death.

author: bmartin

description.text:
These clips can help with loose motor mounts on a Tiko 3D printer. They make sure the motor mounts make contact securely on the rails, otherwise the positioning may be somewhat erratic (at least on my machine). There are also other (more thoroughly tested) fixes you can try on the Tiko forums.

Upper Clips (the small ones)
If you're seeing the same issues with your tiko, this is an easy print for a significant improvement. There are several versions of the upper clips, the larger numbers increase the amount of tension (I'm using 04). You can also scale them to get more fine-tuned adjustment. If they're too tight, there might end up with too much friction to print effectively. These can be attached without any disassembly and should be mounted so the small retaining bump on the inside of the clip is closest to the motor.

Lower Clips (the larger ones)
The larger clips require removing the motor and disassembling them a bit, and I'm not sure it's worth the hassle. I'll probably redesign them when I have a chance, but I figured I'd upload them anyway and so you can try for yourself if you want. They also need a glue dot* or something similar to secure them in place.

Plastic
I printed these clips in PETG, but I think non-transparent ABS will work too. I don't think clips printed in PLA will be useful for more than a couple of days. The clips are designed to be printed with a 0.5mm extrusion width, two shells.

More details at http://thrinter.com/tiko-part-4-fixi…the-motor-mounts/ ‎

Printer:
-- Eustathios

Filaments:
-- Atomic Filament Sapphire Blue PETG

comments.text: These worked great to take out the layer shifting in the crappy Tiko I was given!
comments.author: Estacaco

comments.text: I tried printing the upper clips (the -6 version) in ABS with high infill and 0.30mm layers and I went too far: the hot end never gets low enough to become visible through the clear plastic, and it prints from there...
comments.author: fritztoch

comments.text:
Why do you specifically recommend a non-transparent PLA?

comments.text: It's specifically transparent ABS that I think would be a problem in this application, I find it tends to craze and eventually crack under load, unless it's really overbuilt. More info on my experiences here: http://thrinter.com/walters-filament-collection-abs/#transparent-abs

description.text:
This is a strong adjustable Foot that I designed to level my Vulcanus Max V1.1 printer.

Non-Commercial:
You do not have permission to print and sell this, either as a whole or as individual components. You do have permission to print and test this item for your own use.

Printer:

Self Built Core XY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

PLA

For each foot you need

1x m5 45mm bolt (You can use a m5 35mm bolt if you don't want to tap the bottom of the extrusion.)
2x m5 x10 socket head cap screw
5x m5 nuts

• Press a 5 mm nut into the bottom of the base leg.
  • Insert a 5 mm nut into the center of the base leg.
  • Put a 5 mm nut onto the 45 mm bolt and tighten to the head of the bolt. ( See picture.)
  • Press the bolt head and nut into the foot.
  • File 2 corners of two 5 mm nuts (see picture) and slide into the slots of the extrusions.
  • Install the leg onto the bottom of machine with the 5 mm socket head cap screws.
  • Thread the foot and the bolt into the leg.
  • I tapped the vertical extrusion with a 5 mm tap so the 45 mm bolt would thread into the extrusion to give
    extra strength because I have a large heavy printer
  • you can use a 35 mm bolt if you don't want to tap the extrusion.

and then you are done
made it for a friend

author: direwolf77

title: 31.8 mm Front Derailleur Style Chain Keeper

description.text:
This keeps your chain from falling off a single ring setup.

There are various STLs which documented the cage profile before I trimmed off the extraneous lines, which I kept in case I want to tweak the profile later.

I never use the 52/53 tooth ring for standard road doubles, & I can't fit a 28 mm rear tire in my road bike because of the front derailleur clamp, so I thought I'd go to 1x & get rid of the front derailleur. I don't have a narrow-wide chainring or a clutch rear derailleur, so I'll need one of these to prevent the chain from falling off.

There's a Driveside SLDPRT/STL which is literally just a pole. Hopefully with this close enough of the top, the chain can't even achieve the height necessary to fall off.

Designed for a 38 tooth SRAM Apex 10 speed ring, which is approximately 160 mm in diameter.

Measuring from the center of my seat tube to the middle of the largest ring (double crankset, so the 1x ring will default to the furthest outboard position), I got 49.50 mm.

I measured the distance between the plates on a Shimano Claris FD-2400 to be 13.44 mm, then I scaled that by 1.25 to get a wide width that could accommodate cross chaining to the big cog.

Designed around a 1.2 mm high, 4.85 mm wide zip tie.

For 31.8 mm seat tubes.

These measurements might make the STL useless to you, but you could always just edit the STLs if you want.
Print a non-driveside piece & the driveside variation of your choice. Clamp around your seat tube & zip tie them together.
Never tested yet. Hopefully it's stiff/strong enough to resist deflection from the chain. I didn't close the rear end of the cage because I thought I'd be unnecessary.

title: Monoprice Select Mini E3D 40mm single fan hotend/part

description.text:
V5 - 40mm single fan for MonoPrice Mini Select V1 with E3D hotend. I do not know if this will fit the V2.

Several improvements made:

  • Slimmer profile (less material, less weight)
  • smoothed out the fan side
  • matched screw holes to Us Waterrockets E3D zero offset adapter
  • beveled inside arms for better wire clearance
  • 3 versions, no clips, open clips, closed clips

Rotate and print flat on the fan side with supports. I made mine out of Esun PLA+, 30% infill. Mounting screws are 2x M3 x 25mm. Make sure the heating block is centered in-between the cooling arms.

I've been running the old version since I made it. zero issues but wanted to improve. I used regular PLA and saw no signs of any melting (I print PLA+ at 220).

***The is the redesign (V4) - no longer on site

I wanted a larger single fan mount. I attached the mount from the 30mm (which works really good as is) to the 40x40. The air now blows from 3 directions onto the nozzle. The air vents are also larger and lower.

This is attached using a zero-offset mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848402

I printed mine in PLA at 100% infill, fan side down, with supports. It's keeps PLA temps just fine (200-205) but at 100% it blows too much air, so if you need to go hotter, you'll need to turn the fan down. I ran PLA/PHA at 215 at 70% with no issues.

In my simple bridge test, this is the best result I've had so far. eSun PLA at 200, 40mm/sec. The part on the right is this version of the fan. The part on the left is the last version.

title: Z axis leadscrew support Mod Wilson II

description.text:
This is Wilson II spacific but can be used with any Z axis using Nema 17 motor and M8 leadscrew combination.

Uses: KFL08 8mm Self-aligning Pillow Bearing

Since going to full aluminium coupler with the same result as the printed printed solid coupler but with a better or more positive mechanical grip on the shaft. Now although this works reasonably well I think as higher speed printing I am getting vibrations transmitted into the print.

So to go full circle again I am thinking of re using those springy couplers but in the way they are supposed to be used.

So my thoughts are the bearing takes the load of the X carriage and the springy coupler drives the Z axis and my hope some of the vibration and acceleration and deceleration in Z at high speed print is partially absorbed.

I would just run the leadscrew through the bearing and into the coupler to eliminate another chance of issue but note this will make the leadscrew shoter by quite a bit.

There is a printed adapter shown in the pics but only if you need the lead screw to go to the top mount but there generally is not needed and a lot of setups don't secure the top of the leadscrew..

LulzBot TAZ 6 Custom

comments.text:
Discovering the basic flaw of the Prusa design, copied over and over and trying to resolve it ?
Indeed you are partially on the right track, radial forces causing the "wobble" can be eliminated by using a ball bearing as you do but it is even simpler to do what I did on my Geetech and adapt to your machine.

title: Master Sword - Breath of the Wild Edition

description.text:
After being bummed about missing out the awesome Breath of the Wild - Master Edition, I realized I can just make my own!

I drew inspiration from the statue that was included in the Master Edition, though it is far from a replica. I used the blade as designed by Davidikes (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:282800) and made the base myself. The sword model is cut in half for easy, no-support printing. It also ends in a square cut, rather than the traditional point. This makes inserting it into the base easier, and allowed the base to be shorter, giving the illusion that the blade actually goes through it. The insert for the base has a .25mm tolerance, but it was still tight when I printed it, even after sanding.

First 2 images are the front and back painted, while the 3rd image is fresh from the printer, with ZERO post-processing done. My painting skills are lacking, and I didn't heavily calibrate my machine before such a detailed print, so it looks a bit rough, but it seems to work with the theme :)

I hope to see how awesome this can look with some REAL painting skills.

Thanks everyone!

Update 3 (8/9/2017) - After a computer issue and a scare of losing the original file, I have uploaded a revision of the base to better fit the whole sword (with point). The slot of the sword tapers in, is 20% wider and 30% taller than the original to still give the right scale.

Update 2 (4/2/2017) - At a request, I added 2 new halves of the Master Sword with the point left on. I have NOT tested this, so it may not fit in the base.

Update 1 (1/22/2017) - Added a new file called 'Sizer' that has the same cutout as the base, but is MUCH smaller and quicker to print. This should allow you to find the correct size for the base for your printer, without needed to print multiple bases.

Printer:

DaVinci XYZ 1.0A

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 for sword, .3 for base

Infill:

10% for both

Notes:

Given the small size of the sword, I printed it at exceptionally low speed, to give each layer a little extra time to cool.

title: Peizoelectric sensor based effector for E3D V6

description.text:
This is a combination of all the work done by LeadingLights, Moriquendi ,DjDemonD and Huntley and uses the Nimble to make the whole unit direct drive.

The system is designed to hold a peizoelectric sensor squeezed between the hot end top and the Mount base. You will need some piezo transducers: Murata 7BB-27-4 As 27mm such as
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/391478525842?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Please read the description on DjDemonD's page for mounting instructions and how to prep the sensor. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2034152

Also, check out Huntley's page as it describes the effector in a lot more detail.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1546124

This design is designed for the E3D V6 hot end. The J-Head will probably fit, but is not tested. Overall, the design is checked and the stl files are error free. But it is work in progress.

For those who cannot wait for the Nimble to test this out, use the other mount base.

The Nimble Extruder
With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lighest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and is installable in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available at: https://zesty.tech

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/10G9TH1E07j
  • The HandleStand tilts with a reliable smooth action that is provided by o-rings in the hinges. Your iPhone becomes a totally adjustable table-top camera for FaceTime or video -making.
  • Attachment features (1/4 - 20 nuts) mount the HandleStand on a tripod or monopod in either landscape or portrait orientations. The attachment features will also give you the option to design and print other accessories to be attached to the stand with the iPhone in it.
  • Since the tightness of the fit to the iPhone is controlled by adjusting a zip tie, the HandleStand accommodates all iPhones with or without most cases.
  • For phones in cases that are more than 61mm wide and 12mm thick, set the Scale setting on Slic3r to a percentage appropriately higher than 100%. Enlarging the Handle will make the 1/4 - 20 nuts fit loose and thus require a dab of hot-glue or superglue.
  • The HandleStand makes a great gift!

Materials
(1) Printed Handle
(1) Printed Frame
(2) 4 inch zip-ties
(2) 6 - 32 x 1/2 inch machine screws
(2) 6 - 32 Nyloc nuts
(2) 1/4 - 20 Nuts
Screwdriver, 5/16 inch wrench, wire-cutter (or nail clipper)
  • Use one zip-tie to make a strap across the frame and use the other zip-tie for a buckle.
  • Adjust the fit of the Frame on the iPhone by snugging the buckle on the zip-tie with the iPhone in the Frame. Then remove the iPhone and snug the buckle another click or two.
  • Clip the ends off the zip-ties.
  • Put the hinge screws through the frame first, then put the o-rings on the screws, then put the screws into the handle, then put the Nylock nuts on the screws.
  • Tighten the Nylock nuts to control the hinge friction from the o-rings.
  • Push the 1/4 - 20 nuts into the frame.

description.text:
A simple block to allow the Ultimaker 2 to become direct drive using the Nimble.

The main block holds the top end and mechanicals of the Nimble. The clamp is used to clamp the E3D V6 to the main block and the bottom block is used to clamp the bearing and close it all up. The top bearing is secured using tie-wraps, slots provided.
The only part of the Nimble that is unused, is the bottom half of the housing.

The Nimble Extruder
With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lighest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and is installable in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available at: https://zesty.tech

comments.text:
Why is it the top linear bearing is 35mm long and the bottom linear bearing is 30mm long?
I have some 32mm long linear bearings and need to change some dimensions. Is it possible you could upload the design file or a step file?
comments.author: snipermand

comments.text: ultimaker 2 is a direct drive extruder std, your zesty nimble isn't direct drive because you cannot remotely direct drive anything you either directly drive something or remotely drive something, but you have a dremel shaft between the motor and extruder
comments.author: chris33

comments.text: The filament is driven directly into the hot end, that is what counts in a direct drive extruder, whether the motor is near or not.
comments.author: chris33

comments.text: no its not whats between the motor and the hobbled gear? to directly drive something the hobbled gear has to be on the shaft of the motor take example: geared wade extruder there is gears between the motor and hobbled gear, look at a direct drive which find the hobbled gears on the shaft of the motor, whats between the motor on the nimble shaft and gears so it is not directly driven, your reply 'The filament is driven directly into the hot end' does not describe the type of extruder because every extruder does that or it would not work
comments.author: jamesla

comments.text:
How would you call a geared extruder then ?
So, it is a direct drive, the driving element is NOT the motor, it is the hobbed gear !
Anyway, this system is far superior to a Bowden (even more confusing name isn't it ?).
comments.author: chris33

comments.text: As standard the UM2 is a bowden drive. That is not direct. My comment means that the filament is driven into the hot end by a hobbed gear just above the hot end itself. It's better than the bowden as it remove the guesswork from material flexing.
comments.author: chris33

Simple bracket to mount the Nimble on a dbot and clamping a E3D V6 at the same time.

New Added a bracket including a holder for an induction sensor for bed calibration.

Edit: The original brackets were simply not good enough. V6 didn't fit, was far too tight. Also you needed non-standard length screws to attach to the carriage plate. Thanks for pointing it out Snaggle, much appreciated!

So now there is a little more space around the V6 and the bolts needed to screw into the carriage plate are M3x25.

The STL models are checked and optimised. The parts that need a different orientation to print properly are rotated to the preferred printing position.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

The fusion chess set archi theme. You can play normal chess game with this beautiful architecture inspired chess set, or you can use the special fusion rules for try an new game experience ! When you eat a piece, don't take it off the game, plug it under your pieces and enjoy your new capabilities ! My first try on Tinkercad.
Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/a2jXK6uqwxg

Why kill the chess piece when you take them ? Some warlike tribes ate the hearts of their defeated opponents to absorb their strength. Why don't do that in chess ?
Kill your opponents make you stronger !
Plug him under you, take his ability and go to fight ! For this game you need an classic board and an Fusion Chess Set ! Most of the game respect the official rules, the game is won by taking the King of your opponent.
All the piece keep their ability, move and capture. But, when a piece capture an other one, do pull it off the game, just plug it under your piece.
This way, you won all the moving ability of this piece !
Your piece stay on top and is still the master, you can capture only using his capabilities !
Example : A Knight who capture an Bishop can move like an Bishop and a Knight, but can only capture the Knight way. ;) Exception for the pawn fusion, when you capture one the fusion is total, you can move and capture like a pawn, in more of the master piece abilities, but don't forget that it's an opponent pawn, moving the other way. ;) When an already merged piece capture a new one, pull of the game the previously merged piece and replace it by the new capture, you lost all the abilities of the old one and won the news.
The master piece is still the same. When you capture an merged piece, you only keep the master piece for fusion, his slave is pull of the game. Note : The promotion rule still working (when you advances a pawn to the eighth rank and exchanged with an other piece) but only with non-merged pawn ! You'r free to use this rules or create a new one, only the fun matter !
Exemple of custom rules : Inlimited merging, the fusion keep the capturing ability, when you capture an merged piece, you merge the master and his slaves etc.... If you try this I'm curious to know how was the game with this customs rules.
Will print and try it on the week, i'll tell you.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fWYz4MMhkzh

Introducing TUSH - The Ultimate Spool Holder v.2. I was using a regular spool holder. Not the most convenient design, if you ask me, because It takes some time to replace the roll. Also, based on 608 bearings, It gives more than requested length of filament since there is no traction. That's why I designed this Ultimate Spool Holder. It is simple, easy, sexy and comfy.
For one spool holder you will need to print four pieces of this. Also, you will need four 608 bearings. Get the cheapest ones. They are available everywhere. This is press-fit design. Just press the bearings into the printed part, and voila, you have The Ultimate Spool Holder! Congratulations!

UPDATE: Version 2 uploaded
This is exactly the same TUSH. Just some fixes. Now Simplify3D ans slic3r should be happy with the model. Cheers!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

comments.text: To remove that grease use a sharp knife and pop off that metal cover (don't worry about bending it because it is not useful for non-skateboard uses and will be thrown away) then wipe away the excess with a paper towel then soak the bearing in rubbing alcohol. comments.author: rk3d

comments.text:
You don't have this problem, because - as shown in the photo - you roll off the filament downwards.
That way, the tare on the filament will push the roll always into the TUSH.
If you place the TUSH besides your printer and roll off to an extruder that's higer than the roll, the roll weight is crucial: as soon as there's only a little bit of filament on the roll (and the whole thing gets lighter) the extruder may pull the roll off the TUSH (or crash it).

if you mean the direction of the spokes, yes now i understand what you said but for physics that is the better way, not the opposite.... in fact all producers make chainrings with spokes in this direction ( when you pedal the force is more Orthogonal to the axe) example of one of the most famous : http://lekkie.bike/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/unnamed.jpg

comments.author: emimobilebox

comments.text: Yes exactly if you think about brakes they work with the same forces that act in the exact opposite direction in respect of the chain ring   that is why the brakes spokes are in the opposite direction
comments.author: karnschi

comments.text:
no thats not correct. the forces act in the same direction. on the axe there is a momentum and on the outside is a force acting against it. the direction of rotation is the same and so are the directions of the force and the momentum
there is no difference in the involved forces between a chainring and a brake disc
comments.author: emimobilebox

comments.text: NO man..you're really confused. :-O
comments.author: karnschi

comments.text:
I am sorry but your explanation is so wrong that I dont even know where to start...
trust me I picked up some skills in mechanical engineering during my studies and that is not the way how forces apply...
Let me explain how I see how the forces apply.
First we look at the brake disc. There we have two torques caused by the braking force and the spinning wheel. If the system stands still and there is no rotation then those two cancel each other out. It is called the equilibrium of forces. However the brake disc has to transfer that momentum to the caliper and basically the design of the disc has nothing to do with the distribution of the forces what so ever. The design only makes it lighter and the brakes are designed in a way which makes them stiffer while doing there job. Because metal is stronger when it is applied with pressure than with a pulling force. Therefore the spokes are looking into the spinning direction.
comments.author: emimobilebox

comments.text: No man, I don't agree...and actually the whole industry doesn't agree ...that's why ALL companies with their mechanical engineers make chain rings (and brakes) in accordance to what I explained.  No one makes chain rings as you said, if you where right they would make them that way. You can still do it but in that case it will be just a design choice, less resistant ( it won't get damaged because of the light forces involved anyway).... You can try to propose your vision to the industry, they will give you Pretty much my explanation :-)
comments.author: karnschi

comments.text:
so then tell me why the brake discs are not designed as you told. because the distribution of all involved forces are just the same. the difference is just that while braking you want so stop the rotation and while pedaling you want to start the rotation...
with your explanation mounting the brake discs the way everybody does is also not a fortunate choice
comments.author: emimobilebox

comments.text: Eheheh.... I guess that you missed something in my explanation , the one with pictures. I explained exactly why brakes and chainring are made the way industry makes them....exactly the opposite design because ( hope you get it now) they work with forces with opposite vectors!!! Please read again and see the pics, that will answer your question and you will see why everybody design brakes and chainring the way I say.
comments.author: karnschi

comments.text:
Yes I did get what you wanted to show me with that picture. Thanks for drawing btw but I also refered to you picture in my explanation today. The forces at your chainring in that pic are wrong. There is no pushing force from 1 to 2 at all. If there would be some kind of force that works that way it would mean that there is a pushing force applied by the chain to the chainring. But I hope we both agree that there has to be a pulling force on the chain - no matter how the other mechanics look like! So the chainring has to pull the chain. Therefore the chainring has to transfer a momentum in the clockwise direction from the pedal to the chain. Otherwise there is no movement of the bike.
The pulling force (in the clockwise direction) in the chain is just the effect of pushing your pedal and not the way the reaction forces of the chain is acting in the whole system.
comments.author: emimobilebox

comments.text: yes I did not mention the chain itself to not complicate.... My pictures are correct, but if you want involve the chain just see the green arrow in the left picture, more tangent to the chain, imagine it more a vector as you said...IT STILL HAS part of the direction of the spokes...if you make it inverse as you said the spokes can brake ( is the material is not resistant enough). i work in biomechanics field.
comments.author: karnschi

comments.text:
ok look... I just googled a bit and didnt draw any of those pics myself.
http://www.scielo.br/img/revistas/rbcdh/v14n4/11f02.jpg
http://pinion.eu/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/12-011.jpg
Just to let you know that not the whole industry is supporting your theory...
comments.author: emimobilebox

comments.text:
First pic: no problem, you can even design without holes, of course will be more resistant.
Second pic: in electric bike you can invert the design ( very rare) just because the force will come from the motor hub, not only pedals. It will work but it's not a "pure" design.
Let's say that ALMOST all the industry design and produce exactly as I says , the other few do some experimental design as your second pic. That's fine
comments.author: karnschi

comments.text:
ok we can agree with that. I mean that all is just a matter of design.
But the mechanics overall have nothing to do with the kinematics. The forces are not working just the way you were drawing it in you pics. The distribution of forces is that you have two momentums working against each other. Thats the most basic form of that mechanical problem there is. It cant get any simpler but just more complicated when you want to know how the forces are transfered from the inner side of the chainring where the pedaling momentum is applied to the outer side where the chain is mounted.
When you google chainrings then there are tons of symmetrical ones and also a few with your design but also some facing the other direction. However we both agree that the applied forces are to low to harm any material. But the mechanical distribution of forces is that there is simply one forces pedaling down which leads to a driving momentum and one force pulling on the chain which leads to a load momentum in the other direction. Otherwise those two wouldnt cancel each other out and the rotations speed would increase infinitly...
comments.author: emimobilebox
